'Antwerp' (; , , ) is a city and municipality in Belgium and the capital of the
Antwerp province of Flanders. Antwerp's total population is 512,000 (as of 1
January 2013), [http://statbel.fgov.be/downloads/pop200801com.xls Statistics
Belgium; Population de droit par commune au 1 janvier 2008 ('excel-file')]
Population of all municipalities in Belgium, as of 1 January 2008. Retrieved on
2008-10-19. making it the largest municipality in both Flanders and
Belgium in terms of its population. However the Brussels-Capital Region is
considered as the largest Belgian city internationally. Its total area is ,
giving a population density of 2,308 inhabitants per kmÂ². The metropolitan area,
including the outer commuter zone, covers an area of with a total of 1,190,769
inhabitants as of 1 January 2008. Definitions of
metropolitan areas in Belgium. The metropolitan area of Antwerp is divided into
three levels. First, the central agglomeration (agglomeratie) with 715,301
inhabitants (2008-01-01). Adding the closest surroundings (banlieue) gives a
total of 955,338. And, including the outer commuter zone (forensenwoonzone) the
population is 1,190,769. The French name of Antwerp is Anvers ; it may be
found written this way on signposts in French-speaking parts of Belgium, and French-
language publications.

Antwerp is located on the right (eastern) bank of the river Scheldt, which is
linked to the North Sea by the Westerschelde estuary. The city has one of the
largest seaports in Europe. Antwerp has long been an important city in the Low
Countries both economically and culturally, especially before the Spanish Fury
(1576) in the period of the Dutch Revolt. The inhabitants of Antwerp are locally
nicknamed Sinjoren, after the Spanish honorific seÃ±or or French seigneur,
"lord". It refers to the leading Spanish noblemen who ruled the city during the
17th century. Geert Cole; Leanne Logan, Belgium & Luxembourg p.218 Lonely
Planet Publishing (2007) ISBN 1-74104-237-2
categories: Port cities and towns in Belgium
